title: Can I use my Moto at home to send and accept text messages over wi-fi?

thread.text: I have a Moto phone which I use as a mini tablet. I do not wish to subscribe to a cell network, but I would like to be able to send and recieve text messages with it using my internet service. Is this possible?

replies.text: How do you intend to get a phone number for SMS/MMS?

thread.text:
You'd have to use something like Google Voice. There are apps/services on the Play Store that claim to give free SMS ability to devices that aren't connected to a cellular network, but I'm always a little leery about them.
If you have another cellphone that does have a SIM, you could also try Pushbullet.

There are many services that provide text-like functionality, including Facebook Messenger.
If you do have cell service on any device, does the provider have a messaging app that is not cellular-dependent? For example, Verizon has their own "Message+" app that synchronizes txt messages even with devices that are not cellular (IE, Win10) and may be available for your situation as well.
Also, if you use Verizon, you can sign into the message+ app and access your cell phones text messages over wifi.

Hello Android Central Community! I was wondering if you could help me with a problem I've been having on my Moto Z2 Play. As the subject states, my wifi has been disconnecting and reconnecting from my home network for no apparent reason. This happens when the device is turned off (screen off) and while I'm using it. I do not have it set to turn WiFi off when on sleep. Thanks in advance!

Does this happen on other wi-fi networks, or only your home network? If it's only at home, try rebooting your router by unplugging its power for 10 seconds. See this guide for other tips: http://forums.androidcentral.com/amb...-problems.html
It's other WiFi networks as well, I stated that it was my home network, because, well because I think it was better to include more information than less.

Does this also happen in Safe Mode? https://motorola-global-en-uk.custhe...e-moto-z2-play. If not, then something you installed is probably interfering -- but the tedious part would be to uninstall apps one by one until the problem goes away, since there's no good way to pinpoint it further.
I'll try it out and get back you as soon as I can. I'm not home or near any WiFi connection so I'll update you when I am.
Just tried it, sadly the problem still persists. Sometimes the WiFi will disconnect after I wake the device back up, and it sometimes even happens when I'm using the device.
Ok, that narrows it down to a firmware issue or a hardware issue. Bluetooth can sometimes interfere with 2.4 GHz wi-fi, so see what happens if you turn off Bluetooth for a while.

I usually have Bluetooth off, I'll turn it on occasionally for my Bluetooth speaker, but most of the time it's off. I will note however, that I have an Asus router that uses some kind of smart technology to determine what network to put each device on 2.4 or 5 GHz.

replies.text:
https://www.asus.com/us/Networking/RTAC3200/
This is the beast I have. I did have to disable the "smart switching". What it does, is when the signal gets below a certain threshold, it drops it off that network so it can be forced to another band. On paper this sounds awesome. In practice, it left many devices around my house sitting right on the edge, and constantly looking to switch. Making it seem like they're "disconnecting" from the wifi. Well... they actually are... 
Except for the more powerful network cards on my desktop and laptop computers, just about every phone would randomly disconnect for what seemed like no reason at all.

thread.text: Hmm, that's interesting about the router. Is there a way to turn off that feature, so that it works like a more conventional router? Also, is its firmware up to date?
The firmware is up to date but I'm not sure if you can turn that feature off. I have the model here... https://www.amazon.com/Tri-band-AiPr...cUvbUpU6164877

replies.text: If you read the reviews you can see that a lot of people turned that feature off and got better performance as a result. It is a $400 router, you can turn the smart technology feature off and configure it the way you want to.
Steps to turn off Smart Connect are on pg 105 of the manual: http://dlcdnet.asus.com/pub/ASUS/wir...al_English.pdf

thread.text: Not sure how I missed that. Thank you so much, I'll be sure to try that!

Have you tried turning off wifi scanning?
It seems that both wifi scanning and Bluetooth scanning only cause issues.
I always turn both off. When I get a new phone and forget to turn these off and issue pops up and upon googling it, find a reminder to turn them off. It virtually always fixes the issue.
These settings are difficult to locate.
The easiest way to find them is to go to the phone's main settings menu and type "scanning" in the search bar.

title: Ringtone Repeating Before it Actually Ends

thread.text: Hello Again! I was wondering if anybody had any insight on what I could do about my ringtone and if anybody else had this problem. I downloaded it from Zedge and I've tried another app like it, I just don't remember the name. But basically, my problem is that my ringtone cuts out after about 6-7 seconds and then repeats those 6-7 seconds, even if the actual ringtone is more like 30 seconds, which mine is. Thanks in advance!

It's probably related to those ringtone apps. You don't need a fancy app to make a custom tone. If you wanted to, you could select a full mp3 as your ringtone -- just copy the file to your /Ringtones directory (using a file manager app). If you want to edit it down a little, though, you could use a basic ringtone editor like Ringdroid.
Thanks for the quick reply, I'll be sure to try that out! The only reason I was using Zedge was because I wanted a specific ringtone that I wasn't able to find elsewhere.

With Zedge, you probably don't need the app to access their ringtones. On your computer, go to zedge.net and search for the ringtone. You can download ringtones directly from their site, and then copy the file over to your phone.

Ok, so downloading from my computer and then copying over to my phone should allow the whole ringtone to play out? If that's the case, what do you think is the problem with downloading directly from the app? Again, thank you.

I've never tried it, but I think any mp3 file will play out completely for as long as the phone will ring (which, assuming you have voicemail set up, still shouldn't last for more than about 10 seconds or so). The problem you were facing is likely an issue with that particular ringtone app -- you could try emailing the app developer to see if they're aware of the issue.

any if the battery packs as a starter mod.

Ok, thanks, that's what I was originally thinking because I also liked the idea of keeping the phone battery hovering around 80%. That would help the overall life span of the phone and I saw it was on sale for $60 right now as well.

I have the Tumi 2200mah with wireless charging mounted in my car as a sort of "car dock+ charger", and keep the TurboPower 3490mah on my phone most of the rest of the time. With heavy usage it makes it a good two solid days, and being able to charge both the phone and the mod at the same time (on different chargers) means that I could be ready for another two days in less than 2 hours. I HIGHLY recommend a battery mod. 
I also picked up the gamepad mod when it was "buy a mod, get the projector free" sale at Verizon. It's nice for some games, but not everything plays perfectly well with it. It's well built and is MUCH more responsive than even the xbox controller paired via bluetooth. 
The projector, well, it's pretty cool, even at only 480p. It'll get much more use when it gets warm out and I can do movie nights in the yard with the kids!

Thanks for your quick reply! I was leaning towards the battery mod initially, but now I think I'm just going to go for it, the battery mod that is. Being able to get 2 days off one charge would be amazing! I also love the idea of keeping that battery charged at 80% to help the lengthen the phone's life span. I've been watching the Moto Gamepad and I think I'll just wait until it goes on sale. Thanks again for your input, it is greatly appreciated!

replies.text:
At first I was like you thinking that keeping the internal battery at 80% would be optimum for the battery, but as it turned out it degraded my battery. My internal battery after 1+ years depletes rapidly (when not attached to the battery mod). And there is MUCH discussion here on the forums with others who have found the same thing.
I'd recommend using the battery mod like you plan to, but set it to off (new mod update setting) until you get down to 50 or 40% and then turn it on and let the battery mod do it's thing taking it back to 80% with efficiency mode. I think that way you will extend the life of your internal.
It's a shame they haven't implemented a way to do that automatically with the battery mod software, but hopefully in the future they will let you set the actual percentage you want the battery mod to kick in in addition to the 2 modes they currently have.
Which phone are you describing?
Moto Z Droid

thread.text:
I have a Moto battery pack, it does basically double my Z2's time before charging is required, and I have one of the smaller battery mods. I also have the SoundBoost 2 and a plain back. The only reason I got the plain back is only so I put the phone down on a table and not risk damaging the camera lens or housing. I want the TrueZoom camera, but I can't afford the almost $300 it costs. IMO, the projector is useless.
As to the question as stated, which ONE mod to get? Only you can answer that. What are you looking for on your ONE mod? So far as I'm aware, only the battery mod will actually power the phone (forex, the Soundboost's battery only powers the mod).

Ok, do you use efficiency mode on your Moto TurboPower pack? If you do, how does it help the lifespan of the phone's battery? I wanted to make this phone last as long as possible and I was wondering if the power pack could help me with that.

replies.text:
Nope, I have it in Default Mode. Mine's the Power Pack, not the TurboPower pack. I got the smaller one. 
On light usage, the PowerPack runs out of juice not long before I head to bed. On heavy usage, it'll run out around dinner time. Note that even on "light usage" on a work day, I have a power drain due to crappy signal strength in my office causing the phone to ramp up power to the radio to try to hold onto an LTE signal, failing and then even at times failing to hold onto a basic data capable connection. 
I get better battery life when at home and otherwise the same usage.

thread.text: Much appreciated, and again, thank you very much. Battery mod it is!
Wow, that's a surprise! Thanks for letting me know! Hope they fix that soon.

title: Why did my Moto z2 play just randomly restart without me doing anything?

thread.text: My Moto z2 play just randomly restarted while I was using the moto FM radio app. I didn't tap on anything and it was in the middle of scanning for stations. Suddenly, it disconnected from my JBL smart speaker, and the shutting down sequence initiated. It rebooted and asked for a pin to run android... I put in my lock screen pin and the phone rebooted. It seemed suspicious, so I used my Verizon security app to scan my phone, and it said everything was fine. I haven't owned this phone for even a year, and would like to know why this happened.

Welcome to Android Central! Random reboots happen every now and then, even when everything is working correctly. If it happens once, that's not too worrisome. If it starts happening more frequently, then it could be due to a number of things, including an app you installed that's causing instability, firmware corruption, or a hardware fault.

It's probably happened to me 10 times in the 6+ months I've had the phone. It was only inconvenient one of those ~10 times. 
I have a question for you now. Whenever you re-start your phone (or it re-starts itself), do you get a notification asking if you signed in __ days ago? Where __ is the number of days since you activated your MZ2P? Mine does, and that's really annoying, because it notifies me on every android device.

title: No location access? But it's on!

thread.text:

Device location for all apps is turned off, and you may not be able to locate your device if it's lost
However, location services IS enabled, and all the apps that have requested access have been granted such. Google Maps works, and other apps that rely on the location work as designed.
Z2 Play, current OS, 7.1.1.

Update: I think it actually is turning off the GPS randomly. I just tried to use Android Pay, and NFC was disabled. I did not turn that off, either. And, I have periodically had to enter my password at the lock screen in order to "reactivate" the use of my fingerprint.
All of these items had worked the last time I used the GPS, Android Pay or unlocked my phone.
It's not (shouldn't be) a battery saver thing, as I have that turned off (just checked, it's still disabled) and the power level is fine. There are currently no Mods attached. Last restart was three days ago.
Help?
reboot every morning

title: Android files won't show up on my PC via USB connection

thread.text:
I got a new phone (Moto Z2 Play). When I plug it in to my PC, it shows no files. I can't drag and drop files inside either. I also can't import any files from my phone to my PC. It shows up on my PC but it says "This folder is empty." It's as if my PC sees the phone there but none of its files. Can someone help me get my PC to recognize my files? I am connecting it to a Windows 10 HP Spectre x360 and my phone is a Moto Z2 Play with Android version 7.1.1. I have tried all 3 USB ports on my computer but the issue is the same. The phone is also up-to-date as is my PC.
Thanks so much!

replies.text:
Did you try selecting FOR FILE TRANSFER, from the notification bar?
There should be four or five options. I believe that CHARGING is the default option and that setting prevents the phone from showing properly in MY COMPUTER.
Should look something like the attached pic.
Please reply here if this works.

thread.text:
I used to love Motorola before they were bought by Lenovo. My Moto X Play was the best phone I had ever used at the time. Moto was my go-to for near stock Android without the Nexus/Pixel price tag. Then Motorola got their shoes tied together and delivered Nougat a year after if was originally announced. 
Now I used to steer away from Samsung for lack of updates. But I've had the S8 since October and got all the security updates at the end of each month which is completely acceptable. 
I'm looking at the MZ2P because of its new price and I'm interested in it. But I'm wondering how things are now update wise? Are they delivered quickly (whether they're security updates or point upgrades)?

Updates don't come as quickly as they used to, before Lenovo time, but they are steady. Soak test for Oreo on the Z2 Play has been running for a while and now we got this.https://www.xda-developers.com/motor...2-g5-g5s-more/
Security updates don't come monthly and if this is a high priority for you maybe you should try a different phone (more recent and more expensive).
You're likely looking at quarterly through this summer and it'll get slower when it's replacement comes out.

I have been getting monthly security updates on my Z Play. The most recent one I got was the one for December 2017. They are about a month or two behind Google. However, at least recently they have been coming out pretty much on a regular basis.

Alright it all seems pretty fair. I don't mind it that much if they don't come in monthly (I did get an S8 after all) but I was a bit worried about Motorola after my X Play experience. Now I see even last year's Z Play is getting Oreo at the same time as the Z2 Play making this the second major upgrade for the device in a quite acceptable time frame. 
Plus I'm buying it unlocked because my carrier doesn't have it so monthly updates may be harder to get anyway...

I've had several issues since the last update with the SD card being the biggest problem. I have loved this phone until the update that came along 1-6-18.
Anything I had stored externally no longer works, so images, Amazon music, etc. 
I am running 7.1.1, update NDNS26.118-23. 178.23.12.7
Hope the info is helpful 
Cheers

title: Those going from z play to z2 play?

thread.text: What has been better and what has been worse going from the z play to z2 play?

The Z Play obviously has better battery life and better recharge speed because although similar, you get more juice out of a charge due to Z Play's bigger battery.
Looks are subjective but my friends all prefer the Z2 Play's looks vs the Z Play.
Camera is better on the Z2 Play. Same goes to the in hand feel due to its thinness. I also prefer Z2 Play's metal back in comparison to Z Play's glass back. I find the one hand gestures to be very useful but it did take me a few days to get used to it. 
Audio performance is similar to my ears. Z2 Play has stronger audio jack though, at least from what I can hear.
Other than that they are both very good Moto phones.
Thanks. How much better is the camera?

I have read somewhere the camera hardware is actually comparable to Samsung S8's (hardware. Image processing is another matter). Perhaps it ain't got the best camera in the market but it is right up there for sure.

The z2 play is pretty much an upgrade over the z play, even if pretty minimal at best. Battery is the biggest downgrade but honestly, it isn't too big, even with medium to heavy usage in my case. Slap a battery mod on it and you'll be golden for at least 2 days. Performance is mostly the same, but multitasking is better if you get the 4GB model, which is pretty much a given considering the 3GBs I've dealt with on the Z Play was only okay at best: it got really annoying to reload apps quite more often than I like.
In terms of the actual Z Play I still own, mine had a weird issue along the right side of the display where I could see the adhesive along the right side under the display assembly itself, exacerbated by the fact dust gathers there. Adding to that, you could actually press the display down quite a bit along the top portion of the device. The z2 Play in general feels much more solid, thanks to the back being made with metal as well and the whole phone looks and feels better in overall construction.
There's also one thing I'm going to have a love/hate relationship with this phone: those nice chamfered edges along the top and bottom portion. They give the z2 Play an imho, better aesthetic compared to the z2 Force but you know they'll be scratched in a matter of weeks

I've had the Moto Z Play for awhile now and absolutely love it. Love the battery life. But the port seems to be can't keep a charge and have tried many cords. Same deal. Happened to my nexus 5 also lol. I've been looking at the Moto Z2 Play and I'm thinking it's not that worth it to upgrade too.
Anyone have both phones that could agree? I notice less battery specs, less camera pixels, ect. Idk what route to go now.

I've done a lot of research on the Moto Z2 Play, as I wanted it for a while. Though it has a smaller battery, apparently it does get pretty decent mileage. The gist that I've taken from reviews is, "It's a good phone, but not in a successor sense." According to a carrier site that sells it, you can still get "up to thirty hours" of battery life; which is pretty solid for a phone that did take a hit as far as getting a smaller battery.
If you're a little concerned about getting it, you could always wait for 2018 - Moto's upcoming devices will work with Moto Mods as well, so if you have some, it may be worth the wait. But if your charging port is giving you trouble and you want to upgrade sooner rather than later, what about grabbing something like the G5 Plus to last you until then and then save it as a backup device when you get the next Moto Z Play device that comes out?
I replaced my z force with a z2 play. Battery life seems similar despite smaller battery. I think the CUP is more efficient. Ironically the battery completely died in my Z force after 1 year.

replies.text: Glad you are liking the Z2 Play! I've heard good things about its battery; despite the smaller size.

Good to hear for sure. 
Sent from my XT1635-02 using AC Forums mobile app

My phones tend to be (mostly) naked. My last one, an iPhone, only had the thinnest case I could find in order to merely lift the back up enough so that the camera was no longer protruding. I took a dremel tool and smoothed out the notch on the bumper case and everything fits now.

Quick update... Everything crashed again after the reboot. So it's what I've been told all along by Microsoft, but with a caveat that they did not know about. Depending on how a sd card is formatted, the z2 Play will install apps on the sd card. So I did a reset, reinstalled everything without the sd card installed, and now it works after rebooting... I've since reinstalled the sd card as a sd disk, NOT an internal drive. The problem with that I can't upload apps to the card so I need to mind the internal memory. Right now with everything I want installed, I'm just under 18 gb, so I'm good.

Glad you're sorted. you don't want adaptable storage always grief since Kitkat was launched. Use external. You can still put all your media on there. Google Play films, music, books. And all you photos and films. I have 23 GB on my external.

title: Accidently deleted the Camera file in the cache. Is there anyway to recover the pic without rooting?

thread.text:
I have tried several different free programs I found online but after going through the motions they either tell me the phone isn't supported or must be rooted. I tried several more programs in an attempt to root the phone. 
Is there a clear cut way to recover the pictures that were deleted without jumping through a bunch of hoops?

Welcome to Android Central! What do you mean by "the Camera file in the cache"? Do you mean that you deleted the /DCIM/Camera directory from Internal Storage?
Recovering deleted files from Internal Storage always requires rooting, so unfortunately you will have to jump through those hoops. See this guide: http://forums.androidcentral.com/amb...ted-files.html

I have been trying to find a reputable program for rooting. I found King Root. 
Does any one have any experience with this? If not, are there any others that work well?

I used the files and directions, in the thread below, with no issues.
If you are new to rooting, I recommend much reading and YouTube watching, prior to attempting. Research fastboot commands, TWRP and Magisk.

title: Guess I'm coming back to Motorola

thread.text: Well, after many years of enjoying the Droid series I used a few other phones, most recently an LG G6. After flip flopping a few times trying to decide if I wanted a Pixel2 or Note8 my Verizon business acct was offering black Friday upgrades to Z2play for $0.00 . . Could have had a pixel 2xl for 229 or note8 for 294, but free is free . . Hope I don't regret it, but I did enjoy the Moto version of Android and they do seem to be getting software updates reasonably quickly. Anybody wanting to weigh in on their Z2play experiences feel free to chime in . . . Thanks :-)

So far, I'm liking the Z2 Play. My last Android before this was the original Moto X (os 2.2). The last five years were with iOS.
A few apps I use are not fully compatible, Accu-Chek and MySugar are supposed to support BT data reception from my meter, but don't. Accu-Chek worked on the iPhone so I know it's not the meter. 
Other than that niggle, I'm mostly satisfied with the Z2 Play. I do not have any recent Android competition to compare against.

I've been extremely pleased with the performance and features of the Z2-Play. Even being a "mid range" phone, it performs quite well, in some cases quicker than my fiancees Galaxy S8. It's a bit chunky with the bumper case and the Moto Turbo Power mod attached, but having a nearly 48hr turn around between charges is more than worth it. I get a solid day of high use without the external battery. 
I've even tried to talk myself into upgrading to the Z2-Force, but can't really justify the price when everything works just fine otherwise.

thread.text: In good news the factory reset seems to have done the trick and everything is working again.

Hi, everyone!
I saw the Z2 Play in a carrier store on Monday, and fell in love with it! I may consider a Motorola phone for my next upgrade. How is everyone enjoying the Z2 Play? Any long-term reviews or opinions on things like battery life and screen quality, etc?
Thank you!

I've been using it for several months. I have the Tumi 2200mah battery mod on it almost exclusively. I between that and the abnormally long battery life, I get well over 48hrs with what I would consider heavy usage (streaming music in the car, hotspot to my laptop and tablet, and well over 3hrs of screen on time per day). The lowest I've seen it was the external battery flat and the internal at 40%, and that was after working a 12hr shift, not realizing my charger was unplugged, and going another day after that. 
Screen: It's 1080p, and rather responsive. It's not as "colorful" as my fiance's S8, but its not meant to be. It does ramp up to be readable in bright light. I lose some fidelity with my "anti-glare" screen protector.
The fingerprint sensor is super responsive. I have it set to act as the home button, with the "swipe" to act as as the back/switch app buttons. They never appear on my screen. 
When I picked it up, I got the JBL speaker mod free. It doesn't hold up to the "bigger" bluetooth speakers, but it's absolutely perfect when I'm kicking around the yard to hear my music. 
Don't let the "mid range phone" specs put you off. Side by side with her S8, it's in most cases more responsive.

replies.text: Thank you so much for your review, I really appreciate it! Is the battery module you use super big? I feel like I'd buy it if I did indeed purchase the Z2 Play.

Well, it doesn't feel too thick to me...
But my prior phones were a Kyocera duraforce pro, and a note 5 with a huge protective case. So I may not be the best person to answer that. That said, naked it felt way too thin and hard to hold. The battery made it feel much better. I also put the bumper case that works with mods on it too.
Thank you, that's great to know! I always put cases on my phones - I feel like they are too thin without one!

thread.text:
I've had one for a couple weeks now. I had to get the battery mod (2200 mAh, Moto branded), as this phone does not handle poor connections as well as my prior phone (iPhone 7+) and will drain out twice as fast. Note: The root cause of that is not the phone, it's my location. Where I have a decent connection, it's fine. (NOTE: not asking for help on that, I know of the setting to avoid bad wifi connections.)
The display is the same size in inches as my last phone, but the resolution is less. And I do not notice the difference at this screen size. The higher resolution requires more power and a faster processor, so compared to the Z2 Force, I do have better battery life, and roughly the same overall system responsiveness.
Sound quality on the device could be better. The is no separate speaker from the earpiece for speakerphone / media / alerts, so those may be muted depending on how you hold or carry the phone. Via BT, it's as good or slightly better than other phones I've used.
I wish I had finer grain control over alert/alarm tones. For example, while I can set mp3 files for phone ringers, I cannot for voicemail, txt/sms, email, etc, alerts. This is my first Android in 5 years, so I do not know if this is a limitation of Motorola specifically or Android in general.

replies.text: Thank you so much for your review! With regards to the notification sounds, I feel like there should be a setting (within Sound Settings, most likely?) that should enable you to set a different notification for, say, emails versus SMS. Also, you could download a third-party app like Textra; which could give you different tones for different contacts.
You don't need extra software to set individual tones for contacts. Just edit, and in the edit screen tap the 3 dots icon at the top right.
You need to put sound files into an "alerts" or "notification" folder. That should get you new alert tones.

Thanks!
Same works for "Alarms"

title: Format SD as internal or removable?

thread.text: What are people's thoughts on this? Do you format your SD card to extend the internal storage, or do you format it as removable?

I got the fast card I could find ~ 100 ms and got a warning saying it was slow for internal, Googled it and many have the same issue, and the fastest you can get is a long way off the internal so I used mine as removable, you can still put all your Google stuff on there, music films + photos and films from the camera.
So my Sandisk Ultra is removeable.

I personally think using the card as internal is a bad idea. It's more prone to failure than onboard NAND, and is slower, plus functionality becomes limited. Recent Samsung phones now do have an option to force apps to move to SD card even if the developer set in the app manifest for it not to, so it helps. I don't know if newer Moto has it, but you can try checking in developer options.
So If I had formatted as internal and want to switch it, is there a way I can do that without losing data? Or do I just have to suck it and re-load my media?

I just re formatted mine as removeable and it put everything back (I think) I had to wait for it to finish. You can still eject it when it's internal so it just transfers the folders back I am pretty sure.

replies.text:
I was able to back up the card by plugging the phone into the PC and enabling File Transfer, I was unable to mount the card directly with a card reader.
And, that backup was almost a complete waste of time. I had to then re-delete data for and reinstall several applications that store data on the card, including MediaMonkey, Podcast Addict, PWall, and TomTomGo. And I won't know if that was enough for MediaMonkey until tomorrow morning, as it will take many hours to sync ~7000 tracks of music back over.

thread.text:
I would back up the data on the SD card and then format it, in the phone and start over.
I always choose external. I believe that it provides more flexibility ( I swap phones and move the card, periodically).
I have not read much good experiences using an SD card as internal storage, since the option became available with Marshmallow.

If it's portable (removeable) storage, and you back everything up (to a PC and a cloud account is best, at least for important files), if the card goes, you can always restore the files to a new card. (Most good manufacturers warranty the cards for longer than you'll want to keep them. [SanDisk's warranties are 5 years minimum, Ultra Plus and Extreme cards carry lifetime warranties.]) If it's adaptable (internal) storage and the card goes, there's nothing you can do - you can't back up an adoptable storage card.
But if the phone has limited storage (I'd call 16GB limited these days), you might have to put in an adoptable storage card to make the phone usable for a little longer.

replies.text: Considering the size of the firmware, I'd call 32GB "limited storage" these days. The Moto Z2 Play has 32GB of internal storage, with more than 10GB of that take up by firmware. Something they neglect to tell you at the store.

title: Z2 Play & Z Play: my personal experience

thread.text:
I own both phones (I own the MZP a little longer) and I would like to share my own personal experiences using both devices.
Things that are better on MZP:
1) No question the battery life. I use my devices heavily for WhatsApp and emails and streaming movies on YouTube, and movie streaming services. The MZP, on my estimate, can easily outlast the MZ2P by a couple of hours.
2) Display calibration: I prefer the display on my MZP which has more natural colors when set to standard mode compared to MZ2P's standard color profile. The MZ2P's display has more "pop" even on standard mode. This is really dependant on one's preference though. 
3) Charging speed. I find the MZP can charge just about as fast as the MZ2P, and considering the MZP has the bigger battery, you can quickly top up and have more juice on the MZP.
4) Less camera hump. With the same style shell, the camera hump on the MZP is flush with the body while the bigger hump on MZ2P means even with style shell on, the camera lens may not be as well protected because it is level with the shell.
5) Well, it is quite a bit cheaper than the MZ2P...
Things that are better on MZ2P:
1) In hand feel. Due to its thinner profile and less sharp edges, the MZ2P is quite a lot nicer to hold compared to MZP, which has chunkier body and sharper edges. MZ2P looks more premium too because of this.
2) One Button Nav. I have to get used to this, but after an initial period of adjustment, I find the one button navigation of the MZ2P to be quite intuitive and it also allows more screen real estate.
3) Audio output through the headphone jack seems more powerful on the MZ2P. 
4) Bigger RAM and internal storage compared to MZP.
Overall, both are fantastic devices but if you have to choose one device between the 2, I would advise picking up the MZP: it is cheaper, performance is smooth, battery life is quite a bit better in my experience(can opt out of buying the battery mod), although it is a chunkier device and the in hand feel is less premium than the MZ2P. 
Now I use the MZ2P as my daily driver, while the MZP is my "media consumption" device due to its longer battery life.
What about the camera differences?

replies.text: They're both pretty decent but the MZ2P takes slightly better pictures to my eyes but both struggle in low light. I do own a camera though so I use the MZP and MZ2P just for taking casual snapshots mostly.

title: Moto z2 Play not charging with Car USB

thread.text: Hey yall, just got the Moto Z2 play the other day. I was with a friend and my phone battery got low. I plugged into the car usb and later realized it wasn't charging. Is there a reason the charger didn't work? I used the same cord at home and it was fine with a wall outlet.

without knowing what car charger you were using, there are a few possibilities.
First may be that the charger wasn't powerful enough to charge the phone.
Car charger may have been off (was the power port [lighter] in the car powered on?, some are off when the car is off).
Port may not supply power. Some "ipod" ports don't supply ample power, but rather are mainly used for data connection to the radio.
If it is a vehicle factory (or a port on an aftermarket radio), let us know the vehicle or radio make/model.
If it's a "plug into the lighter" type plug, see what the amp/volt output rating is. Test with other phone, adapter may be faulty, since your cable is known to be good.

Under powered charger, insufficient for USB-C charging, perhaps?
What are the output amps of the charger used?

title: How many hours are you getting for screen on time on your z2 play?

thread.text: Title is self-explanatory, I want to make sure I'm not losing too much compared to z play. Thank you

this may be a near pointless question, unless people include what brightness level they keep their screen at, whether they have Bluetooth turned on all day for headsets or smart watches, how long they are on the phone for calls, if they have location enabled, etc.
Even many of those things drain battery with the screen off, it still affects the amount of screen time possible in any full charge cycle.

gee, speaking of pointless, thanks for the helpful reply, I do pretty much know what I'm talking about, but if you think you're helping me then fine . . . I would generally expect people to sketch their typical usage along with their answer but didn't think I needed to spell that out

Revtech, my apologies, my hastily typed reply wasn't meant as a criticism of your question, but I can see how it came across that way due to the "pointless" remark, so I accept your wrist slap.  I should have phrased differently.
Fwiw, the sentiment just stems from the many long battery threads I've seen that weren't as helpful as they could have been for those of us trying to diagnose poor battery life (which I realize isn't your situation).
Again..sorry for my poor choice of words.

I've been surprised because of the smaller battery in the z2 I was expecting to see alot of those battery threads you mentioned but I haven't seen any helpful ones in this forum yet . . no sweat on the apology, I was probably just as snarky but yes the word "pointless" kinda set me off but I can tell now you're a decent guy, so my turn to apologize now 🙄 . . . Either way I'd still like to know if the z2 play gets through a heavy usage day or not, I don't care about "two-day" battery life, but I'd like to think it still gets through the day with lots to spare . . I've read the reviews but was looking for some real world over time usage numbers

Well, I'm further embarrassed to tell you I'm not even a Z2 Play user, though I seriously considered one a few weeks back due to dismal battery life collapse on my Moto Droid Turbo 2, which has a huge battery. After reading the same reviews you probably did of Z2 Play and Force Edition, I concluded Z2 Play would be the optimal choice on both cost and battery life, despite its battery size reduction. I'm not afraid of smaller batteries *if* overall power draw is better managed, esp. screen draw. (The 720p 2013 Droid Maxx was a brilliantly balanced design in this respect.)
Hopefully lack of battery discussions is a sign of high satisfaction with battery life on this new model. Since the very launch of the 2015 Droid Turbo 2 I have, there've been seemingly constant threads due to many owners not seeing anywhere near the Verizon and Moto touted numbers, e.g. <2 hrs screen time, while others loving life at 5+ hrs screen time. Nougat update seemed to drive many of us down even further. I've come to suspect the DT2 suffered a batch of bad original batteries, and/or a power draining bug in the radio software stack. 
FWIW, I wound up having a $70 OEM battery replacement installed on my DT2, and now getting 14+ hour standby and 3 hour screen times far beyond any I had even when it was new, as measured by GSam Battery Monitor Pro. I'm a pretty heavy user, frequent Bluetooth, high power location services, Moto Voice enabled, etc.
I'm hopeful to hear that your two year newer Z2 Play sees even better numbers than those. Good luck!

With WiFi, Bluetooth, precise location, medium brightness, 3 push email accounts with 100 messages a day, 150 texts, and what I would call average use I get 6 hours of screen on time as reported by GSAM and generally cannot kill the battery in a single day. Best battery life on a phone I have ever seen. I bought the battery mod and never use it.

With Wi-Fi on, three email accounts with probably around 50-75 total messages a day, checking news, a few videos, no gaming, but screen on for at least half the time, at end of ~12 hour day, my Z2 Play, unlocked on VZW, has about 60-70% battery remaining. It's much better than my unlocked Moto X Pure ever was, and certainly reasonable for a relatively small battery.

So battery life on my Z2 has been nothing short of awesome. I can easily get through a normal day (normal for me). In fact my average per-hour drain is around 2% (2.5% if I really push it). I'm not playing games on it but using it for browsing, phone calls, email, calendar. So no complained about a running averaging 35-40 hours.
But, the biggest battery drain by far is 
-Cell Standby 19% according to Android OS 
-Phone Radio 44% according to GSAM
The phone radio awake time is 100% which I suppose makes sense. I would not want the phone actually disconnecting from cellular. But that still seems high. My last monitoring session had over 5 hours of screen on time and still screen power use was half of the phone radio power use.
Cellular signal is poor where I live and work but am connecting to strong wifi almost all of the time in both places.
On one hand I am super happy with overall battery life. One the other hand I wonder if it could be even better without the phone radio drain? 
What is everyone else seeing?

replies.text:
I'm on the OG Z Play, so I can't speak to user experience on the Z2. However, since it sounds like you've identified your main issue (i.e., poor signal), you may want to force the phone onto its non-LTE radios and use those. A great app to do this is called "Radio Switcher" in the Play Store. 
*Generally speaking*, the 4G/HSPA signal is stronger in most locations than LTE is. Using the non-LTE radios also has the added benefit of saving you some juice, as the LTE radios drain your battery a bit faster. Doing this MIGHT alleviate your drain issues. Downside: data speeds are a bit slower, though I use 4G regularly to stream audio and video with no issues.
Glad to hear the phone is treating you well overall. I just recommended the Z2 Play to a friend and will likely upgrade to it myself sometime in the next several months. Good luck!

title: Z2 Play review a week in

thread.text:
I have had the Z2 for a week and thought I would post some thoughts. I am coming from iPhone 7 realized I needed a larger screen more than I needed the pocketable size of the iPhone 7. iPhone 7 Plus seemed like a natural choice but iPhone 7 Plus is crazy expensive and with new iPhones just around the corner it seemed silly to drop $1000 in a 7 Plus right now. Great time to check out Android!
I actually tried a Samsung S7 first. With some of the crazy discounts being offered, the S7 is half the price of the iPhone 7 Plus and a great deal. The S7 unlocked phone shipped with marshmallow but immediately updated itself to nougat after I set it up. 
I was disappointed in the S7. Battery life was less than I expected and I noticed lag straight out of the box. It had so many killer features on paper but the overall experience (for me) just didn't feel great. I thought "if it is this laggy and the battery is already not awesome, it will only get worse in the future." 
I ended up returning the Galaxy after 3 days. 
The Moto Z2 play seemed intriguing. Midrange specs in just about every way kind of put me off, but the price was right and the mods seemed kind of interesting. The idea of a cleaner Android was pretty appealing.
After a week, here is what I think of the Z2 Play:
Speed - fantastic! Not laggy at all and very smooth. Even when running multiple apps the Moto just feels fluid and graceful. I cannot understand how the Moto Z2 processor is half the speed (single core) of the S7 and yet feels as fast or faster. But it does. I have watched plenty of speed test comparisons on YouTube and the S7 seems to only beat the Moto in loading time tests of big games. I don't play games like that much and don't care if they load 3 seconds slower. Overall, for day-to-day operations the Z2 flies!
Screen - great! To me the Moto Z2 screen looks really good. Maybe a tiny bit less sharp than the Samsung but still very good. Colors look natural and contrasty. The only negative I've noticed is that the Moto in direct sunlight isn't the brightest and at night the minimum brightness is still too bright. Being Android, I was able to easily download a little utility that reduces minimum brightness. Problem solved!
Battery life - outstanding! Easily gets me through a heavy day with room to spare and charges incredibly fast. No weird battery drains or runaway processes. I read that battery life was reduced compared to the Z Play, which may be true. But who cares with life this good?
Moto software - Genuinely helpful. I love the "open doorknob for camera" and "tomahawk chop for flashlight" gesture controls. I love the "show me" voice commands. I like the swipe controls on the fingerprint scanner. I like the lock screen functionality. I love that the Moto just knows when I'm driving and switches to a completely voice-based system for texts. Why doesn't every phone have that driving mode?? Brilliant! 
Build - very nice. The metal back and chamfered edges look high quality. Even the large camera bump out is nicely made. The Z2 Play feels solid and looks like a high quality phone.
Camera - better than I expected, but not amazing. The camera takes very good photos in bright light. Well saturated, well exposed, and sharp. There may be a bit too much software sharpening, but most pictures look good. Low light photos are another story. The lack of OIS means the photos are grainy (due to high ISO being necessary) and still blurry (unavoidable camera shake). I wouldn't say the low light shots are terrible. In fact, they are useable. But low light pictures are definitely below the S7 and even the iPhone 6s. 
Mods - more interesting than I expected. I have the wireless charging+battery extender, the JBL speakers, and a Style Shell. I've used the JBL as much as a high-quality speakerphone as anything else, and it works great!. Sure, I could buy a standalone bluetooth speaker but the sheer convenience and ease of use of the JBL is hard to beat. Likewise, the battery mod stays in my travel bag and I can either leave it attached during long travel days or slap it on for a quick charge and then take it off again. Either way, I appreciate that it doesn't make my already tall phone taller as most other phone battery packs do. The Style Shell looks really nice and actually makes the phone easier to hold. In general, I like the idea of the mods more than I expected. They are expensive though, and I wish there were more of them. Maybe beyond batteries and case backs there just aren't that many legitimate uses for mods. (the projector mod is cool, but I'm not sure how often it would get used) Still, Moto executed mods well and they do add value to the phone. 
What don't I like? Not much. 
Waterproof - nano coating is nice, but not the same as the flagships IP67 or IP68 ratings. With S7s and soon to be iPhone 7s dipping much closer to the Moto Z2's price, a nano coating just isn't enough.
Camera - adding OIS would have made a huge difference to camera quality and I would happily pay a bit more for it. 
Size -the Leno Chin and Frankenstein Forehead are necessary to retain compatibility with Moto mods, but definitely they make the Z2 Play a physically large phone which is somewhat dated looking. 
Overall for me the Z2 feels like more than the sum of its parts and is a very enjoyable phone. On paper, it should fall to even last years flagships which are now similarly priced, but I think the Moto holds its own in terms of overall experience vs. those devices.
Thanks for your review! I'm happy to hear battery life remains solid, the Z Force last year was a great device.
Thank you so much for your review! So glad you are liking it, and that the battery life is working well for you. It's a great phone, for sure! Also, how "big" is this camera bump?

The camera bump is big when the phone is naked. it's that size to help anchor mods when they are attached. honestly it looks better to me than the iPhone camera pimple. put a style shell or a mod on the phone and the camera bulge vanishes.

title: Post Pictures taken from your Z2.

thread.text: Let's see how well the camera does. Post your pics.

Just got a Z2 Play last night. I took a few shots this morning and compared them with an iPhone 7 (not the Plus). 
My impressions are that the Moto camera software applies a lot more sharpening than the iPhone (and more than other camera phones I have seen). I really noticed it as sharpening halos around the leaves of the palm trees. . That could also be purple-fringing reduction algorithms as dark tree leaves against a bright background are notoriously tough for creating purple fringing on digital cameras. I see no evidence of fringing so some software corrections are happening. 
Overall, the Moto Z2 photos are sharp (right on the verge of being crunchy) and look pretty good. Exposure is slightly under, probably somewhere on the -1/3 side which I prefer to the iPhone actually. I didn't like the darkening of the Moto sky, making it look almost grey at the top. In fairness to Moto, I've noticed the iPhone 7 doing that a lot too but in this case the iPhone 7 sky looks much better. 
For the indoor shot, I prefer the Moto picture hands down. Colors seem more saturated, the sharpening really helps with the overall scene here, and I think the contrast is higher (more pleasing to my eye). The iPhone photo looks slightly washed out in comparison. And yes, I realize the two compositions are not identical but hey, this is a quick snappy comparison :-)
Considering the list price of the 2 phones is $250 apart I think the Moto is holding its own pretty well. 
The flower photo is also interesting. I tried much harder to frame exactly the same perspective on both phones. The Moto must have a slightly wider lens because I had to get a bit closer to the flower on the Moto than I did on the iPhone to make the picture nearly identical. The Moto depth of field is shallower in general and when combined with being slightly closer it renders the flowers less in overall focus than the iPhone. The background is more blurred to on the Moto, so overall the Moto has a shallower depth of field. 
Hard to say which of these I prefer. I like the colors on the Moto a little better than the iPhone, but I think the iPhone is pulling in a bit more detail (even allowing for the deeper depth of field). the center of the sunflower in the iPhone shot seems just a bit more detailed.

I took a few more outdoor shots. Clearly excellent conditions - lots of light! Still, the pictures to me look very good. I didn't see any of that janky grey sky. Also, the exposure metering to me looks spot on. Colors don't have the oversaturated look of the Samsung (but lets be honest, also awesome look of the Samsung) but aren't washed out either.
I was particularly impressed by this interior courtyard shot. Very hard to meter and the Moto did well! A few blown out highlights (the white shirts of people) but overall metering is about what I would have done manually. Sky isn't blown out even though it is a bit lighter than actual, nor are the darker areas just a muddy dark mess. Sharpening is maybe a tiny bit too high but I'm very happy with the shot.

title: A few days using the Z2 Play

thread.text:
Been using the Z2 Play for a few days and it's the first mid-tier phone I've used since the smartphone craze began. Usually go for the flagship models, whether it's an iPhone, the Z Force Droid, the S8+, etc. So my experience is probably colored by those phones. 
Have been using the Verizon model, 32 GB, 3 GB RAM with a 128 GB Samsung EVO Select U3 micro SD card inserted. I'll be returning the Z2 Play for a couple reasons, the main ones being the lag, the camera and the much slower download speeds.
-- I hadn't realized that chip architecture can limit download/upload speeds until reading about it in-depth, after noticing how much slower my downloads were, as compared to my other phones. My FiOS gigabit connection gets me at, or near, 500 MBs download on my other phones, while capping out around 110 with the Z2 Play. 
-- The lag is there, especially on apps such as Facebook and Google Photos. Editing a picture on Google Photos leads to a "wait" splash screen that forces me to close the app and re-open. (I've recreated that annoyance about five times.) 
-- The camera just isn't that good. Oh, bright light and outdoors it'll snap a nice picture, but inside, or in lower light, the lack of OIS reveals itself. 
-- On the plus side, it's a great looking and feeling phone. I use a Moto Modo black leather back and the Z2 Play feels great in the hand with it. I will say the battery was a pleasure, but with only using it for a few days, I can't say it's a battery beast. Not enough time for that. Also, even at Full HD, the screen seemed plenty bright enough in the sunlight. And there is still nothing to compare with Moto Actions. Flipping the wrist to activate the camera makes me smile every time, especially when watching somebody stumble to get the camera up on their iPhone. (Why the hell hasn't the great, almighty Apple implemented quicker camera access?)
So guess it'll be the new Z Force, whenever that drops, as I am a big fan of the Moto Z line and Moto Mods. I'm guessing the Z Force camera and processor will boost it back to what I consider "normal." I'm not here to rip the Z2 Play, I'm simply pointing out that to me it was a noticeably different experience from the flagships.

I've owned and have followed Moto's phones for about 7 years now. I pay close attention to their cameras because after battery it is second on my list of priorities for a phone. 
From what I've read it's like the typical Moto camera. Takes great photos in good to decent light. While the low light photos are an improvement over past Moto phones, they are not up to Samsung, Pixel, and LG quality. And of course, they suffer from blurry photos of action shots, largely because they don't have OIS. The Z2 Play seems to open the app and is ready to take shots faster than any previous Moto phone, according to the reviews I've seen so far.
I guess my advice is the same as it's always been for Moto phones. Hold the phone with two hands, brace an elbow on something stationery, hold your breath and tap the screen to take the shot. This is especially true for low light shots or action shots. I've noticed their newer phones--Play Z, Force Z, Z Play--actually have a built in message reminding the shooter to hold the phone steady.
So, Moto is incrementally improving their cameras. While they are getting better and better, so are the other manufacturers so they never catch up.

title: Don't be fooled buy Best Buy website description, as I was :(

thread.text: Ordered the Z2 Play from Best Buy website yesterday, for in-store pickup. The website description clearly states 64 GB storage and 4 GB RAM. Went to pick it up today, box label lists 32 GB storage and 3 GB RAM. They said the website must be incorrect. No kidding.

replies.text: With phones, their website is messed up a lot. i would never trust their website.
First time there's ever been a glaring inaccuracy for me.

thread.text: Thanks for the heads up
Doesn't surprise me. best buy is known for incorrect product description problems. They should take it back with no restocking fee though... You might have to fight depending on the store.

replies.text: No restocking fees for me. Elite status and all, since I spend so much there. (Much to the chagrin of my better half.  )

thread.text:
This happens often locally for me, often I see devices with the incorrect specs next to them (online store or in promotional magazines) For example a Samsung Galaxy A3 (2017) will have 32gb storage with a 16mp camera on their website but if you do a search only the A5 & A7 have it 😃 
Always good to just double check things before purchase. I've been burnt before so this is what I do now.

Best Buy still hasn't fully corrected their listing for the Verizon Z2 Play. The main ad still shows the wrong specs. But if you click on the product questions link it shows the correct ( 32GB ROM/ 3 gig RAM ) specs.

replies.text:
Downsizing the battery?! Nooooo...
My upgrading choices are between the Z2 Play, the HTC U11, and the Axon 8 (once we know more about that). So far, looks like HTC has me.

thread.text: Nope, not at all. It has not even been officially announced yet, so everything "leaking" at this point is just rumors and speculation.

replies.text: You're right about it being speculation at this point. Hopefully the rumours are proven wrong!

The leaks are mounting though and coming​ from increasingly credible seeming sources. Additionally, Moto has a clear incentive to reduce the battery size. For one, people seem to lap up thin phones. And secondly, it makes their battery Moto mods more attractive. If the new Moto branded power pack mod is as thin as the reports suggest (and the phones price stays the same) I suppose I won't mind. If the stock battery is 3000ish and the mod ads another 1000, that's PLENTY of juice.

I definitely understand what you're saying. If Motorola wants to push their modular market, then making the battery a bit smaller would be a wise move - and, of course, the slimmer phone design would work in conjunction with that. I wouldn't mind having a thicker phone if the battery was bigger! But I get that a lot of users are trending towards slimmer phones.

I use the Z Play as my daily driver and love it. I also have the JBL mod that I got for <$50 , which I love. By itself I have zero issues with the phones dimensions. But add a mod and it does get chunky. The new Moto branded battery mod due to drop this summer is supposed to be very thin tho, so it should be a good one to use for us 1st gen Z Play users.
That's great to hear about the mod! I'm excited for Moto.

But they have confirmed it on Twitter.
Check out @lenovo's Tweet: https://twitter.com/lenovo/status/86...834732545?s=09

thread.text: One tweet doesn't prove much

replies.text: If it's from Lenovo's official Twitter page, and doesn't subsequently get removed for error, that ups the confidence interval substantially.

thread.text: I think it's pretty disappointing. I really loved the z play last year. What a surprise phone for me. Didn't think I was interested in the mods, but since I liked the phone so much I bought a few of the style ones and the jbl. Literal two day battery life, so didn't ever really have to worry. It was great for vacations. Intended to buy this years too but even if optimized a battery that size won't last two days and I don't want a battery mod. Once you buy that the phone ends up costing more than what it is worth imo. If the other rumored specs are true, it doesn't sound like there's much incentive not to just got find an old zplay and get that instead.
Mod not: Moved to Rumored Devices Forum.

Looks like they killed the Z Play with mods, stole the name and gave it to the standard Z successor. Then said "hey! Why don't we make a Z play without the mods, that will be greaaaaaat!" Hence we get the rebirth of the Moto X. 
I'm beyond pissed I bought two battery mods (yes I use them on the play all the time, size is not an issue) and a speaker mod.
Why can't the Moto X4 have mods too!?!
That 660 processor in the X4 better be wayyy more efficiant than the 625 in the Z play... I still needed mods even with the big battery to get 2 day battery life, now it's more like two mods after half a year of battery ware and tear.

replies.text: Per Jerry on recent AC podcasts, the 660 is sort of a more efficient 820. Don't expect the 660 to be a battery god.
